text: hello welcome to 10-minute tutorials for
research my name is josiah bjorgard and
i'm a senior partner solutions architect
at aws
today i'm going to tell you about
storing results with amazon bracket
bracket uses s3 the amazon simple
storage service
this is an object storage service
offering industry leading scalability
data availability security and
performance
and while there are many use cases for
s3 you don't need to dive too deep into
the service to use it with amazon
bracket it's efficient to know that this
is where your data is stored
when you first start using bracket
you'll be greeted with a dialog
box that says choose your data storage
you can use this dialog box to create a
new s3 bucket
or select an existing s3 bucket
it's important to note
that the requirement for using an s3
bucket with amazon bracket is that the
name of the bucket starts with amazon
dash bracket
whether you're creating a new bucket or
selecting an existing one
a quick review on how to specify a
device and run a task and then access
its results on bracket
you'll specify a device using the aws
device object
and then you'll execute a circuit using
the run command
i won't show you how to create a circuit
in this tutorial
but it's contained in the bell variable
in this example
after the task is run you'll be able to
access the results using the result
function
and then you can print out a number of
measurement
measurements like measurement
probabilities
in this example we didn't specify an s3
bucket when we used the run command so
bracket used a default s3 bucket
here's an example
i've created the default amazon bracket
bucket using the dialog box when i first
started bracket and if i don't specify
that as my
target s3 bucket bracket will use a
default bucket that it creates
named amazon dash bracket dash the name
of the region that you're running in
dash
the account number that you're using
you can see two of those here one for us
east one and one for us west one
you can then
print your result
and what bracket does
is it
downloads the result from the s3 bucket
when you run the result function
and then you can access the data that's
provided in that result
you can also specify a custom s3 bucket
at runtime
in this case you'll specify the bucket
name
here's titled examplebucket which isn't
a realistic name for an s3 bucket you
could put in the name of the default
bucket that's created when you start
using amazon bracket
if you don't recall that was amazon dash
bracket dash a unique id that's created
automatically for you
then you'll enter a prefix
prefix is much like a folder
and that helps you organize your results
in your custom s3 bucket
after you put these two items together
in a variable you can now use them when
you use the run function
here you can see i've added that s3
folder variable to my run function
this task will now store
the data that contains the circuit
results in this s3 folder
that you've you've specified and you can
access them in the same way as if you'd
use the default s3 bucket
by not specifying an s3 folder variable
but what happens if you lose the task
variable for example if you restart
your
managed notebook
well you can go to the the amazon
bracket console and go to the tasks
menu on the left hand side
in here you can find your task
and
you can select the arn this is a unique
identifier for your task that you can
use to load it
back into your
managed notebook
you can also see the s3 bucket
and folder that this task has
selected
for storing its data
you'll use an aws quantum task object
and then specify the arn here where the
task id variable is
this creates the task and downloads the
data from the s3 bucket
that is part of that task id
and you can load your result
using the result function and analyze
the results as before
thank you for attending this 10 minute
tutorial for research
you can practice retrieving your results
on amazon bracket using the techniques
you've learned in this presentation
a great place to get started is the
getting started folder in the bracket
example notebooks
my name is josiah bjorgard thanks again
